prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her having five kids with different fathers is why she's single. The friend was making hurtful comments, and the author finally snapped by pointing out the friend's situation. 

First, I need to assess the context. The friend had been making personal attacks for two years, like commenting on the author's weight or job. The author tried to brush it off, giving generic advice. Then, when the friend asked why she couldn't get dates, the author responded with the truth about the five kids and child support.

The mutual friends are now criticizing the author, saying they're privileged and a bad friend. The author feels wronged because they worked hard and didn't mean to be harsh. 

I should consider if the author's response was justified. The friend's behavior was definitely disrespectful, but the author's reply directly called out a personal issue. Even if true, bringing up someone's personal life in a harsh way can be seen as crossing a line, especially if it's not the first time the topic was brought up. 

The author might have a valid point about the friend's situation affecting her dating life, but the way it was delivered—during a conversation filled with insults—could be seen as adding insult to injury. The friends' reactions suggest that the author's comment was too personal and hurtful, even if the intent was to be honest.

Also, the author's job in the adult industry might make others judge them more harshly, which could explain why friends are taking the friend's side. The author's response might have been a defensive reaction after being attacked, but it still could be seen as unkind.

In the end, while the author had been wronged, the direct and personal response might be considered inconsiderate. There might have been a better way to address the situation without attacking the friend's personal history. So, the author is probably in the wrong here. Answer A.
